title: 1  Reference Frames
text:
1.1 Why Rotations
We use rotations to answer two different questions…

Given \(P\), what are the coordinates of that same point relative to \(F_j\)?

Answer looks like: \({}^j(P_0) = R_j P\)

Given \(P\), what are the coordinates of a point in \(F_2\) that are rotated about some axis?

Answer looks like: \({}^2(P) = R_i P\)


How can we reconcile this?

\(R_j \equiv R_i^T\)

title: 1  Reference Frames
1  Reference Frames
text:
1.3 Euler Axis Rotations
There are many ways to describe rotations about multiple axes. One way is to apply a sequence of rotations about principle axes, applying each rotation to the preceding intermediate frame. This technique is known as euler sequence rotations.
You might say: to get frame \(B\), rotate frame \(A\) by \(\theta_1\) degrees about frame \(A\)’s \(X\) axis, then rotate that intermediate frame \(\theta_2\) degrees about the intermediate frame’s \(Y\) axis, etc.
Euler ZYX: \(R_z(\theta_3) R_y(\theta_2) R_x(\theta_1)\)

title: 1  Reference Frames
text:
1.4 Fixed Axis Rotations
Fixed XYZ: \(R_x(\theta_1) R_y(\theta_2) R_z(\theta_3)\)

title: 2  Kinematic Descriptions
text:
2.1 Modified DH Parameters
Given a specific serial manipulator, you may apply the following steps to construct the Modified DH parameters. Note that Modified DH Parameters are not unique. You may select multiple sets of parameters which yield the same kinematics.

Copy the contents of Table 2.1, where \(N\) is the manipulator’s number of joints, and \(i\) is the index of the current joint you’re inspecting. The frame with index \(0\) should be the base frame or world frame: some frame from which all joint positions can be referenced.



Table 2.1: Template for Modified DH Parameters Table


\(i\)
\(a_{i-1}\)
\(\alpha_{i-1}\)
\(d_i\)
\(\theta_i\)




1






2






…






\(N\)









For each index (row), assign the corresponding link frame axes and fill in the values for the parameters \(a\), \(\alpha\), \(d\), and \(\theta\) using the rules presented in Figure 2.1. The index offset \(i-1\) in the column headers can be confusing. To be clear, the first values you will fill in are \(a_0\), \(\alpha_0\), \(d_1\), and \(\theta_1\). The next values are \(a_1\), \(\alpha_1\), \(d_2\), and \(\theta_2\).




Assign axis \(\hat{z}_i\) to the direction of joint rotation if revolute, or joint translation if prismatic. Assign axis \(\hat{x}_i\) in any direction that is not the direction of \(\hat{z}_{i+1}\); if you can while satisfying this condition, assigning \(\hat{x}_i\) in a direction pointing towards the next joint is helpful. Place the origin of frame \(i\) where \(\hat{z}_i\) and \(\hat{x}_i\) intersect.
The link length \(a_{i}\) is the distance from \(\hat{z}_i\) to \(\hat{z}_{i+1}\) along \(\hat{x}_i\). Usually this value is positive or zero; negative \(a_i\) values are discouraged. If your selected \(a_i\) is negative, consider changing your definition of \(\hat{x}_i\) in Rule \(1\).
The link twist \(\alpha_{i}\) is the angle from \(\hat{z}_i\) to \(\hat{z}_{i+1}\) about \(\hat{x}_i\).
The joint offset \(d_{i}\) is the distance from \(\hat{x}_{i-1}\) to \(\hat{x}_{i}\) along \(\hat{z}_{i}\).
The joint angle \(\theta_{i}\) is the angle from \(\hat{x}_{i-1}\) to \(\hat{x}_{i}\) about \(\hat{z}_{i}\).

title: 3  Jacobians
text:
3.1 Derivations
The translation and rotation Jacobians can be derived using two methods: direct differentiation, and the cross-product method.
\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x} \\ \dot{y} \\ \dot{z} \end{bmatrix} = J_T \begin{bmatrix} \dot{q_1} \\ \dot{q_2} \\ ... \\ \dot{q_n} \end{bmatrix}
\tag{3.1}\]
\[
\begin{bmatrix} \dot{p} \\ \dot{q} \\ \dot{r} \end{bmatrix} = J_\Omega \begin{bmatrix} \dot{q_1} \\ \dot{q_2} \\ ... \\ \dot{q_n} \end{bmatrix}
\tag{3.2}\]
